choices.text: Deficiency of G6PD occurs only in red blood cells.
The HMP shunt involves one reversible reductive reaction followed by a series of phosphorylated reactions and sugar inter conversions.
Deficiency of G6PD → inability to keep glutathione in reduced functional form.
The reduced NADPH formed during the shunt is utilized in fatty acid oxidation.

questions.text: A child was recently diagnosed with G6PD deficiency. Glucose 6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) catalyzes the regulatory step in the HMP shunt. Which is the correct statement about G6PD and HMP shunt?
questions.solution:
Ans. C)  Deficiency of G6PD → inability to keep glutathione in reduced functional form.        

 

Option C:

                                                                            

  • Reduced glutathione is an important antioxidant.
  • The NADPH is supplied by the oxidative reactions of the pentose phosphate pathway which is regulated by the availability of NADPH at the G6PD-catalyzed step.
  • The pathway involves two irreversible oxidative reactions, each of which generates NADPH. The NADPH is used in fatty acid synthesis, steroid hormone and cholesterol synthesis.
     

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Deficiency of G6PD occurs only in red blood cells: The oxidative phase of the pathway is seen in Liver, Adipose tissue, Adrenal cortex, Testes and ovaries, RBCs and Lens of eye. The non-oxidative phase is present in all tissues.

 

Option B. The HMP shunt involves one reversible reductive reaction followed by a series of phosphorylated reactions and sugar inter conversions: involves two irreversible oxidative reactions

 

Option D.  The reduced NADPH formed during the shunt is utilized in fatty acid oxidation: used in fatty acid synthesis, steroid hormone, and cholesterol synthesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

G6PD is an enzyme in the hexose monophosphate shunt that is responsible for the production of NADPH. NADPH is crucial for maintaining the reduced form of glutathione, a critical antioxidant in cells. In G6PD deficiency, the reduced production of NADPH leads to a reduced ability to maintain glutathione in its reduced form, making red blood cells more susceptible to oxidative damage.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 196-200.

questions.text: Identify which of the following pathways does not produce high-energy phosphate compounds directly helps in comprehending the energy dynamics within the cell.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) HMP Pathway.

 

Option B:

 

The Hexose Monophosphate (HMP) pathway, also known as the Pentose Phosphate Pathway (PPP), is primarily involved in the production of NADPH and pentoses (5-carbon sugars) rather than the direct synthesis of high-energy phosphate compounds like ATP or GTP. NADPH is crucial for biosynthetic reactions and antioxidant defense, but the pathway itself does not directly produce high-energy phosphate compounds.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. TCA cycle: This cycle includes steps that produce high-energy phosphate compounds, such as the substrate-level phosphorylation generating GTP.

 

Option C. Glycolysis: Glycolysis directly produces ATP through substrate-level phosphorylation in two steps.

 

Option D. Beta-Oxidation of Fatty Acid - Each cycle of beta-oxidation generates FADH2 and NADH, which contribute to ATP synthesis through oxidative phosphorylation, albeit indirectly. However, considering the overall process and its contribution to ATP generation, it's included among the pathways that produce high-energy compounds.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pathways which do not synthesize ATP are
 

  • HMP Pathway
  • Rapaport Luebering Cycle
  • Uronic acid pathway
  • Alpha oxidation of Fatty acid
  • Omega Oxidation of fatty acid

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9/e: 253.

choices.text: Oxidized form of nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide

questions.text: A middle-aged woman visited a region with known chloroquine-resistant malaria. As a prophylactic measure, she was administered primaquine. Shortly after starting the medication, she exhibited signs of hemolytic anemia and was later diagnosed with a deficiency in glucose 6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD). Given the role of G6PD in cellular metabolism, what is the underlying cause of her hemolytic symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Decrease Level of Reduced Glutathione 

 

Option D:

 

Glucose 6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) is the rate-limiting enzyme of the pentose phosphate pathway (hexose monophosphate shunt), especially important in red blood cells.

  • G6PD’s main role:
    • Catalyzes the conversion of glucose 6-phosphate to 6-phosphogluconolactone,
    • While reducing NADP⁺ to NADPH.
  • Why is NADPH critical?
    • NADPH maintains glutathione (GSH) in its reduced form.
    • Reduced glutathione (GSH) is essential for neutralizing reactive oxygen species (ROS) and protecting red blood cells from oxidative damage.

 

In G6PD deficiency:

  • RBCs can’t generate enough NADPH,
  • Leading to decreased reduced glutathione levels,
  • Making cells highly vulnerable to oxidative stress (e.g., from primaquine, sulfa drugs, fava beans),
  • Resulting in hemolysis (breakdown of RBCs), as seen in this patient.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Oxidized form of nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD⁺)
    → NAD⁺ is used in glycolysis and the TCA cycle, not in the pentose phosphate pathway or glutathione regeneration.
  • Option B. Glucose 6-phosphate
    → Substrate for both glycolysis and HMP shunt, but not directly involved in antioxidant defense or in the cause of hemolysis here.
  • Option C. Ribose 5-phosphate
    → Product of the non-oxidative phase of the HMP shunt, important for nucleotide synthesis, but not relevant to oxidative stress handling.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

In G6PD deficiency, red blood cells have:

  • Impaired ability to handle oxidative stress
  • Low NADPH levels
  • Decreased reduced glutathione (GSH)

 

This makes them susceptible to hemolysis, especially after exposure to oxidant drugs like primaquine.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 586, 693-694.

questions.text: A 1-year-old child with a diagnosed inborn error of the pentose phosphate pathway is brought to the clinic for a follow-up. The child has a history of hemolytic anemia and developmental delays. The pentose phosphate pathway is crucial for producing NADPH, which is essential for maintaining the reducing environment in cells. Given the importance of this pathway, which of the following organs is least likely to contain enzymes for an active pentose phosphate pathway?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Skeletal muscle

 

Option D:

 

Skeletal muscle does not have a high demand for the pentose phosphate pathway's activity under normal conditions. The pentose phosphate pathway is most active in cells that are engaged in rapid anabolic activities, such as the liver, which is involved in metabolic regulation, the adrenal glands, which synthesize steroid hormones, and red blood cells, which require NADPH to prevent oxidative damage. In contrast, skeletal muscle's energy needs are primarily met through glycolysis and oxidative phosphorylation, and it typically does not require the large amounts of NADPH produced by the pentose phosphate pathway.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adrenal Gland: Has a high demand for NADPH for steroid biosynthesis, therefore has an active pentose phosphate pathway.

 

Option B. Liver: A major site of various metabolic processes including gluconeogenesis, fatty acid synthesis, and detoxification, all of which require NADPH from the pentose phosphate pathway.

 

Option C. Red Blood Cells: Rely on the pentose phosphate pathway to generate NADPH, which is essential for protecting hemoglobin from oxidative damage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

HMP shunt:  Involved in synthesis of NADPH and Pentoses.

 

Uses of NADPH

 

  • Reductive biosynthesis of fatty acids, cholesterol, steroid hormones & bile acids.
  • Cofactor for glutathione reductase and MetHb reductase
  • So HMP shunt is active in: Adipose tissue, liver, RBC, ovary, testes, adrenal gland and lactating mammary gland.

 

Sources of NADPH:

 

  • HMP (G6PD and 6 phosphogluconate dehydrogenase)
  • Malic enzyme
  • Isocitrate dehydrogenase (Cytosolic)

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 196-200.

questions.text: In the context of cellular metabolism and redox balance, which pathway is primarily responsible for the generation of NADPH, a key factor in protecting cells from oxidative stress?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) HMP shunt

 

Option C:

 

NADPH is predominantly produced by the hexose monophosphate shunt (HMP shunt), also known as the pentose phosphate pathway. This pathway operates parallel to glycolysis and is essential for providing the reducing power in the form of NADPH for biosynthetic reactions, antioxidant defense mechanisms, and detoxification processes, particularly in tissues actively engaged in lipid synthesis, such as the liver, adipose tissue, and adrenal glands.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glycolysis: While glycolysis is a central metabolic pathway for glucose breakdown, it does not produce NADPH; instead, it generates ATP and NADH.

 

Option B. Citric acid cycle: The citric acid cycle, also known as the Krebs cycle, is involved in cellular respiration and produces ATP, NADH, and FADH2, but not NADPH.

 

Option D. Fatty acid oxidation: Fatty acid oxidation, or β-oxidation, primarily generates acetyl-CoA, NADH, and FADH2, not NADPH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • NADPH is used for reductive biosynthetic pathways such as fatty acid synthesis, steroid and cholesterol synthesis and Amino acids by Glutamate dehydrogenase.
  • NADPH is required for regeneration of reduced Glutathione which clears free radicals from erythrocytes and lens.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e p197.

choices.text: Serves as a source of NADPH, essential for reductive biosynthesis and detoxification.
Plays a role in preventing the formation of methemoglobin by maintaining reduced glutathione.
Is directly implicated in causing free radical injury due to its metabolic processes.

questions.text: In a clinical case discussion, a medical student presents a patient with a genetic defect impacting a key metabolic pathway, leading to abnormal red blood cell function. The discussion focuses on the role of various metabolic pathways in cellular health. The student is asked to identify which of the following statements about the hexose monophosphate (HMP) shunt does not align with its known functions.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Is directly implicated in causing free radical injury due to its metabolic processes.

 

Option D:

 

The HMP shunt, or pentose phosphate pathway, is not known to cause free radical injury. On the contrary, it generates NADPH, a critical cofactor in the reduction of glutathione, which in turn plays a vital role in protecting cells from oxidative stress and free radical damage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Serves as a source of NADPH: True, the HMP shunt is a major source of NADPH, which is crucial for various cellular functions including reductive biosynthesis and the detoxification of harmful substances.

 

Option B. Provides Ribose 5-phosphate: True, one of the outcomes of the HMP shunt is the production of Ribose 5-phosphate, a necessary component for the synthesis of nucleotides and nucleic acids.

 

Option C. Plays a role in preventing the formation of methemoglobin: True, NADPH produced by the HMP shunt maintains the reduced form of glutathione. Reduced glutathione is essential for the reduction of methemoglobin back to hemoglobin, thus preventing methemoglobinemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Biochemical Significances of HMP Pathway

 

  • Alternative route for metabolism of Glucose and causes complete oxidation of Glucose
  • Major function is to generate NADPH and Riboses
  • No ATP is generated by this pathway
  • Free radical scavenging
  • Maintain RBC membrane integrity by keeping GSH in reduced state
  • Prevention of met-haemoglobin formation
  • Detoxification by hydroxylation
  • Maintain the transparency of lens
  • Bactericidal activity of macrophages

 

Ref: Harper 30/e p197.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male patient with Mediterranean origin travels to Africa. During his trip, he develops symptoms of malaria and is subsequently treated with primaquine. Shortly after treatment, he presents with signs of hemolytic anemia. His medical history is significant for a specific enzyme deficiency that makes him susceptible to hemolysis when exposed to certain oxidative stressors, such as primaquine. The enzyme deficiency is involved in which of the following metabolic pathways?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) HMP pathway

 

Option C:

 

The patient's condition suggests a deficiency in glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD), which is a key enzyme in the hexose monophosphate (HMP) shunt, also known as the pentose phosphate pathway. This enzyme deficiency is common in the Mediterranean population and can lead to hemolytic anemia upon exposure to oxidative agents such as primaquine. The HMP pathway is responsible for producing NADPH, which is crucial for maintaining glutathione in a reduced state, thereby protecting red blood cells from oxidative damage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glycolysis: While glycolysis is a central metabolic pathway, a deficiency in glycolytic enzymes typically does not result in hemolytic anemia precipitated by primaquine.

 

Option B. Gluconeogenesis: This is the process of generating glucose from non-carbohydrate substrates, and deficiencies in gluconeogenesis enzymes do not typically present with hemolytic anemia upon primaquine treatment.

 

Option D. Rapaport pathway: This is not a recognized metabolic pathway related to the condition described; it may be a misnomer or confusion with the Rapaport-Luebering shunt, which is involved in regulating 2,3-BPG levels in red blood cells, not directly related to oxidative stress response.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glucose 6 Phosphate Dehydrogenase Deficiency –

 

  • Most common enzyme deficiency in human beings.
  • X-linked recessive
  • Manifest as - Hemolytic Anaemia OR Methemoglobinemia

 

DRUGS CAUSING HEMOLYSIS IN G6PD DEFICIENT INDIVIDUALS

 

  • Sulfonamides
  • Chloroquine
  • Quinine
  • Primaquine
  • Nitrofurantoin

questions.text: Identify which of the following metabolites is not typically involved in the HMP shunt?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Glycerol 3 Phosphate

 

Option A:

 

Glycerol-3-phosphate is not a metabolite of the HMP shunt. It is involved in glycolysis and lipid metabolism, acting as a connection between these pathways, but it is not a part of the HMP shunt. The HMP shunt primarily produces NADPH and ribose-5-phosphate for biosynthetic reactions and does not directly utilize glycerol-3-phosphate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sedoheptulose-7-phosphate: This is a seven-carbon sugar phosphate that is indeed an intermediate of the HMP shunt.

 

Option C. Glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate: Although it is also an intermediate in glycolysis, glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate can be produced in the HMP shunt as well.

 

Option D. Xylulose-5-phosphate: This is a five-carbon sugar phosphate and is one of the metabolites of the HMP shunt.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Metabolites in HMP Shunt Pathway

 

  • Glucose-6-phosphate
  • 6-Phosphogluconate
  • Ribulose-5-Phosphate
  • Xylulose-5-Phosphate
  • Ribose-5-Phosphate
  • Glyceraldehyde-3-Phosphate
  • Sedoheptulose-7-Phosphate
  • Fructose-6-phosphate
  • Erythrose 4 Phosphate.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p197

questions.text: Which of the following metabolic pathways is not directly involved in the generation of ATP?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) HMP Pathway.

 

Option D:

 

The HMP Pathway, also known as the pentose phosphate pathway, does not generate ATP. Its primary functions are to produce NADPH for reductive biosyntheses and to provide ribose-5-phosphate for nucleotide synthesis. Unlike the other pathways listed, the HMP Pathway's role is not in energy production but in biosynthesis and maintaining redox balance.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Glycolysis: Glycolysis is a fundamental metabolic pathway that converts glucose to pyruvate, generating a net gain of 2 ATP molecules per glucose molecule.

 

Option B. TCA Cycle: The TCA Cycle, or Krebs cycle, occurs in the mitochondrial matrix and produces GTP, which is equivalent to ATP, along with NADH and FADH2, which are used in oxidative phosphorylation to generate further ATP.

 

Option C. Fatty Acid Oxidation: Fatty acid oxidation, or β-oxidation, takes place in the mitochondria, breaking down fatty acids to acetyl-CoA and generating NADH and FADH2, which are then used in the TCA cycle and oxidative phosphorylation to produce ATP.


Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p200.
